questions.text: Which of the following structures of the inguinal canal lies outside the internal spermatic fascia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ilioinguinal nerve

The ilioinguinal nerve lies outside the internal spermatic fascia of the spermatic cord.

questions.text: Bronchopulmonary segments are aerated by which of the following bronchi?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tertiary bronchi

Bronchopulmonary segments are aerated by tertiary (segmental) bronchi. Each lung is divided into 10 bronchopulmonary segments, and each segment is supplied by a specific segmental bronchus and its accompanying blood vessels. 

Lobar Bronchi:
The main bronchi divide into secondary bronchi (also called lobar bronchi), which supply each lobe of the lung. 

Segmental Bronchi:
Lobar bronchi further divide into tertiary bronchi, also known as segmental bronchi. 

Bronchopulmonary Segments:
Each segmental bronchus supplies a specific, pyramidal-shaped region of the lung, known as a bronchopulmonary segment.

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Falciform ligament

The structure marked A is ventral mesentery. The falciform ligament derives from the ventral mesentery, which is a part of the embryological foregut and forms a connection between the ventral abdominal wall and the liver.

questions.text: 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Levator veli palatini
Levator veli palatini is not derived from first pharyngeal arch.
All soft palate muscles including levator veli palatini are derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch and are supplied by vagal plexus.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cyst on the neck anterior to the sternocleidomastoid at the junction of the upper and middle third of the muscle. This cyst is due to the persistence of which of the following embryological clefts?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2nd cleft 

A cyst presenting at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border is most likely a branchial cyst. It develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. .

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Muscle glycogen phosphorylase
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle’s disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency. The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles.

questions.text: Fluoroacetate is a component of pesticides. Which of the following metabolic pathways is inhibited by this compound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

TCA cycle

Fluoroacetate inhibits the TCA cycle enzyme aconitase. Fluoroacetyl CoA condenses with oxaloacetate to form fluorocitrate which inhibits aconitase, causing citrate to accumulate. This way it inhibits TCA cycle enzyme non- competitively.

questions.text: After evaluation, a child with severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperuricemia is diagnosed with von Gierke’s disease. What is the inheritance pattern of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Autosomal recessive

Von Gierke’s disease is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait. Deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase causes this glycogen storage disorder.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with corneal opacity, deficiency of which of the following could be a likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Keratan sulfate


Keratan sulfate I is present in the cornea. It is present between the collagen fibrils in the cornea and plays a major role in corneal transparency. Hence, its deficiency can lead to corneal opacity.

questions.text: Which anticoagulant present in the light blue vacutainer is used for coagulation studies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sodium Citrate

Light blue vacutainers contain the anticoagulant sodium citrate.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland, which causes primary hyperparathyroidism (not secondary).

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


 VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine. Peristalsis involves the contraction of a segment of intestine behind the bolus of food and relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus of food.

choices.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the point marked on the myocardial action potential curve.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


The myocardial action potential curve marked above represents the plateau phase, which is due to the slower and prolonged opening of calcium channels. Two types of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (T­ and L-types) are present in myocardial cells. The opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels is mostly responsible for changes in the action potential. The action potential curve of cardiac muscles consists of 5 phases,

choices.text: From point D to point A
From point A to point C
From point D and point B

questions.text: A patient has a resting heart rate of 82 beats/min, normal blood pressure, and normal body temperature. What is the extent of diastole in the ventricular pressure-volume relationship?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

From point D and point B
 Diastole includes the isovolumetric relaxation period (D to A) and ventricular filling (A-AV valve opening- to B -AV valve closure-). Thus, the diastole extends from point D to point B.

questions.text: Which structure carries axons from the nucleus gracilis to the thalamus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Medial lemniscus
The medial lemniscus conveys axons from the nucleus gracilis and cuneatus to the thalamus.

questions.text: A 15 year child has a limp in in his left leg. Clinically there is some swelling in the lower thigh. An X ray shows a codman trangle. Biopsy from the tumor is as shown in the image, the tumor cells show a translocation 11;22. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
Ewing’s Sarcoma. Histology shows a small round cell tumor with Homer wright rosette further tumor cells showing t(11;22) is diagnostic of Ewing’s sarcoma. Tumor marker for Ewing’s sarcoma is CD99.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of a palpable mass in both breasts. Histopathology examination shows the following finding. Immunohistochemistry showed estrogen receptor positivity. Which protein that maintains cell adhesion, and thereby inhibits cell motility, is mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

E Cadherin

The given scenario is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast which involves mutated E-cadherin protein. In this condition, the histopathological examination shows infiltrating small monomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in an Indian-file or single-file pattern.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with chronic hepatitis B infection comes for a follow-up visit. Which of the following is not a histopathological feature of the liver in such cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ballooning degeneration 

Ballooning degeneration is not associated with chronic hepatitis. It is seen in acute hepatitis.

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was he most likely working in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Asbestos

From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the histopathological image showing asbestos bodies, ferruginous bodies, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

questions.text: An elderly male working in a factory manufacturing PVC pipes is at risk of developing which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Angiosarcoma

Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with carcinogenic exposures to polyvinyl chloride.
Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that primarily affects older adults. The tumor often involves the skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. Angiosarcomas are locally invasive and can readily metastasize.

questions.text: A 28-year old man presents to the clinic with complaints of lower back pain and passing dark red-colored urine. He was diagnosed with malaria and is on antimalarials for the past 3 days. The peripheral smear of the patient is shown below. What is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


 The given scenario is suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. It is the most common enzyme deficiency in humans, inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder. The gene that codes for G6PD is located in the distal long arm of the X chromosome at the Xq28 locus. The inheritance pattern is similar to that of hemophilia and color blindness, where males usually manifest the abnormality and females are carriers.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man patient presents with anemia and abdominal pain. On examination, he has pigmented macules over the palms, soles, and oral mucosa. Further investigations reveal loss-of-function mutations of the STK11 gene. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


The given scenario is suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Loss-of-function mutations of STK11 cause the Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. The STK11 gene, also known as LKB1, encodes a serine/threonine kinase that is an important regulator of cellular metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of the following pathological change seen in the spleen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


The above image shows a pale, wedge-shaped area of infarction in the spleen. The most common cause of splenic infarcts is a thromboembolism. The pattern of ischemic necrosis in the spleen is coagulative necrosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and macroorchidism. Cytogenetic analysis reveals an expanded CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene. Which of the following genetic disorders is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and macroorchidism, along with an expanded CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene on cytogenetic analysis, is consistent with Fragile X syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and smoky, cola-colored urine 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. He is found to have periorbital edema and mild hypertension. Urine examination shows dysmorphic red cells and red cell casts in the urine with mild proteinuria. Which type of hypersensitivity is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephritic syndrome due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. This is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML-M3). Which of the following is a characteristic of this acute myelogenous leukemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Auer bodies in blast cells

Auer bodies are slender, pink, staining rods containing lysozyme, and are exclusively seen in AML. Although similar to normal azurophilic granules in content and staining properties, they are distinguished by their gigantic size. Special stains can enhance the detection of Auer bodies. They are only seen in a minority of cases. The Philadelphia chromosome is a feature of chornic myelogenous leukemia (CML), and a high leukocyte alkaline phosphatase level is seen in patients with a high WBC due to a leukemoid reaction.

questions.text: A child 8 years old, presents in the emergency department after ingesting multiple tablets accidentally. He exhibits severe symptoms such as diarrhea, urination, sweating, and respiratory distress. Upon examination, constricted pupils and crepitations in both lower lung lobes are noted. No vascular or CNS effects are observed. What drug could be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Neostigmine
This is a case of neostigmine poisoning in which the patient presents with complaints of accidentally swallowing multiple tablets of a drug. Neostigmine's mechanism of action involves inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine, thereby enhancing cholinergic activity at the neuromuscular junction. There were no vascular or CNS effects which suggest an indirect cholinergic agent. The drug poisoning has cholinergic effects suggested by diarrhoea, urination, sweating, miosis and bronchoconstriction and Increased respiratory secretions.

questions.text: Which of the following is adverse effects of high-dose continuous inhaled salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hypokalemia 

Hypokalemia is a possible adverse effect of continuous salbutamol therapy. It is caused by β2-agonist stimulation of the Na+/K+-ATPase, which leads to an intracellular K+ shift. Hypokalemia can cause ECG changes, such as T wave flattening, ST depression, and U waves.

questions.text: A 16-year-old teenager is going on his first deep sea fishing trip and is using a scopolamine patch to ward off sea sickness. Which of the following is the most likely adverse effect he will experience?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Drowsiness

Scopolamine penetrates the CNS and can cause drowsiness and sedation. It also can cause mydriasis, tachycardia, and urinary retention.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient comes to the clinic complaining of warts on his penis for the past 1 week. During the physical examination, the warts are found to be painless, and the inguinal lymphadenopathy noted is also painless. A diagnosis of syphilis is established. Given this diagnosis, which antibiotic should be administered to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Benzathine penicillin G

Benzathine penicillin G is the treatment for Syphilis as it is long-acting and can perfectly cure the disease • Penicillin G is short-acting. To overcome this problem, Benzathine and procaine groups can be added to penicillin G to make it long-acting. Benzathine penicillin G is the longest acting penicillin. It is slowly absorbed into the circulation after IM injection and hydrolysed to Benzylpenicillin in vivo. It is the drug of choice when prolonged low concentrations of Benzylpenicillin are required and appropriate, allowing prolonged antibiotic action over 2–4 weeks after a single IM dose.

choices.text: Isoniazid acts by inhibiting the formation of the mycobacterial cell wall
Streptomycin acts by inhibiting the transcription of RNA
Rifampicin acts by disrupting the cell membrane

questions.text: The patient is prescribed an anti-tuberculosis regimen. Which of the following drug is with the correct mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Isoniazid acts by inhibiting the formation of the mycobacterial cell wall 

Isoniazid inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acids, which are essential components of mycobacterial cell walls. Isoniazid is a prodrug that is activated by KatG, the mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase. The activated form of isoniazid forms a covalent complex with an acyl carrier protein (ACP) and Kasa, a beta-ketoacyl carrier protein synthetase, which blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient is diagnosed with candidiasis. The patient is started on a drug that works by creating pores or channels in the fungal membrane of candidiasis. Which of the following is the most likely drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nystatin 

The most likely administered drug is Nystatin. Nystatin: Binds ergosterol (unique to fungi); forms membrane pores that allow leakage of electrolytes. It used topically in the management of oral candidiasis, vulvovaginal, oropharyngeal and cutaneous candidiasis. Binds ergosterol (unique to fungi); forms membrane pores that allow leakage of electrolytes. It is used topically in the management of oral candidiasis, vulvovaginal, oropharyngeal and cutaneous candidiasis

questions.text: Of the following, which is a phase II biotransformation reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sulfate conjugation 

Phase II (or synthetic) reactions, which almost always result in the formation of an inactive product, involve conjugation of the drug (or its derivative) with an amino acid, carbohydrate, acetate, or sulfate. The conjugated form(s) of the drug or its derivatives may be more easily excreted than the parent compound.

questions.text: Certain drugs, such as chloroquine, require a high-loading dose followed by regular maintenance doses. Which of the following factors does this loading dose depend on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Volume of distribution 

The volume of distribution in the body determines the loading dose of any drug being administered. The distribution volume means how much plasma is required to accommodate the whole drug if the plasma concentration remains constant.

questions.text: Which parameter is depicted by point X in the graph?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Therapeutic window 

The therapeutic window is the range of doses effective for treating a condition with minimal adverse effects. The range between the minimum toxic dose and the minimum therapeutic dose is called the therapeutic window and is of practical value in choosing the dose for a patient.

choices.text: These act by increasing cyclic AMP
These activate a tyrosine kinase enzyme
These activate a nuclear transcription factor

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of thyroid hormones T4 and T3 at the thyroid hormone receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

These activate a nuclear transcription factor


Thyroid hormones T4 and T3 act through intracellular receptors, which function as nuclear transcription factors. These receptors are located inside the cell and regulate gene expression by binding to specific DNA sequences. Upon hormone binding, the hormone-receptor complex translocates into the nucleus and binds to hormone-responsive elements (HREs) on DNA. This binding initiates the transcription of target genes, leading to the synthesis of proteins involved in various physiological processes. Activation of nuclear transcription factors by thyroid hormones represents a slower but long-lasting mode of action.

questions.text: A neonate was diagnosed with meningitis. The organism showed resistance to bacitracin. What is the most likely cause for this neonate’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

Streptococcus agalactiae
Streptococcus agalactiae is a group B streptococci that shows Beta-hemolysis on blood agar, is resistant to bacitracin, and gives a positive CAMP test.

questions.text: Pencil-shaped macroconidia is a feature of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

Trichophyton
Pencil-shaped macroconidia is a feature of trichophyton.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, vomiting, and watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having consumed shellfish and raw seafood a day before. The causative agent showed the Kanagawa phenomenon on Wagatsuma agar. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus
Kanagawa Phenomenon is shown by Vibrio parahaemolyticus. The Kanagawa phenomenon is hemolysis on wagatsuma agar.

questions.text: A patient was infected by Bacillus anthracis. Under which of the following bioterrorism categories does this organism fall into:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

Category A 
Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of passing loose bulky stools that were associated with abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. Stool examination reveals an organism with 4 pairs of flagella exhibiting falling leaf motility. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
 

Giardia lamblia
The given clinical history and microscopy of an organism with 4 pairs of flagella and falling leaf motility is suggestive of giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia.

questions.text: A farmer presented with a traumatic ulcer in his right eye. Microscopy was done which showed septate hyphae. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
 

Aspergillus
The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and microscopy showing septate hyphae given is Aspergillus.

questions.text: Two days after the administration of penicillin, a patient developed hemolysis due to antibodies produced against the drug. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

Type II 
Development of antibodies resulting in hemolysis after penicillin administration is an example of a type II reaction. This is a drug-induced type II hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not caused by exotoxins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

Meningitis
 

Meningitis is not typically associated with exotoxins.
Meningitis is most commonly caused by bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis) or viruses (e.g., enteroviruses) that directly invade the meninges without relying on exotoxin production.

questions.text: A male patient presents with hydrophobia, tearing, and altered sensorium after a dog bite. You suspect rabies in this patient and take corneal scrapings to confirm the same. What test is performed to obtain the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

Reverse transcription-PCR for virus
Detection of rabies virus RNA by RT-PCR(reverse transcriptase -polymerase chain reaction) on corneal scrapings is highly sensitive and specific.

questions.text: A patient recently returned from sub-Saharan Africa presents with painless haematuria. This structure was found on microscopy of urine. It was measured at 125 micrometers in length. Identify this structure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

Schistosoma haematobium
This is an egg of Schistosoma haematobium, recognised by its characteristic size (110-170 micrometers in length), internal miracidia and terminal spine. The terminal spine differentiates it from Schistosoma mansoni and Schistosoma japonicum.

Ecological/ Co- relational Study

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Tribal and hilly areas should have one health sub-center for a population size of how much?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

3000

According to the present norms, tribal and hilly areas should have one health sub-center per 3000 population, one primary health center per 20,000 population, and one community health center per 80,000 population.

45 mg iron and 400 mcg folic acid
50 mg iron and 350 mcg folic acid
100 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid

questions.text: Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat programme, what dose of iron and folic acid tablets will you prescribe for a 6-year-old child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

45 mg iron and 400 mcg folic acid 
Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat programme, a 6-year-old child should be given 45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid (1 iron and folic acid tablet weekly). The tablet is sugar-coated and pink in color.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the immunization programme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

TT/Td
In the given scenario, a ten-year-old schoolchild will be administered the TT/Td vaccine according to the National Immunization Schedule.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gray
This patient with vaginal discharge and erosions on the cervix has cervicitis from a sexually transmitted infection. She should be given the gray kit which contains cefixime and azithromycin.

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week

questions.text: What is the dosage of vitamin A given for a 2-year-old baby with keratomalacia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks
The recommended vitamin A dosage for a 2-year-old child with keratomalacia is 2,00,000 IU given immediately, followed by the same age-specific dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks.

High stationary  → Early expanding  → Late expanding→ Low stationary → Declining

questions.text: An epidemiologist is studying changes in the population of a country with time. This process is called the demographic cycle. Which of the following options best defines the correct sequence of the phases of the demographic cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

High stationary  → Early expanding  → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining
The correct sequence of the phases of the demographic cycle is High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters can be used to measure the rate at which the death is occurring from different causes in a given population, during a specified period?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

Specific death rate

questions.text: What does number 9 in the given diagram related to hypertension denote?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
 

Adequately treated
The above diagram depicts the rule of halves, which is observed in hypertension, and “number 9” denotes adequately treated subjects.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of acute encephalitis in the community and a vaccination drive is launched. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Live and subcutaneous 

The given scenario is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis for which a live vaccine is administered subcutaneously.

Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

questions.text: The Chadah committee recommended all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

One PHC for 50,000 population
The recommendation of one PHC for a 50,000 population was given by Kartar Singh Committee.
The recommendations given by the Chadah Committee of 1963:

questions.text: You are part of a rural health camp organized under Project Axshya. Which of the following diseases does it aim to control?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 

Tuberculosis
Project Axshya was launched in 2010 to control TB. Axshya means free from TB which is the ultimate goal of the project and the National TB Elimination Programme.

questions.text: While examining the skeletal remains from a bomb blast, a forensic expert decides to use the Gustafson’s method for identification of the ages of people killed. Which of the following would you not assess in this method?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tooth length

Tooth length is not assessed in Gustafson’s method. Gustafson’s method of estimation of age of an individual is based on physiological changes in teeth. It is mainly useful in adults over 25 years of age.

questions.text: The autopsy done in a case of poisoning reveals the leather bottle appearance of the stomach. Which of the following is the likely poison ingested by the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Phenol

The autopsy finding of leather bottle appearance of gastric mucosa is characteristic of carbolic acid (phenol) poisoning.

questions.text: The autopsy report of a victim of homicide revealed the cause of death as smothering and traumatic asphyxia. Which of the following best describes the crime?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Burking

Burking is a combination of smothering and traumatic asphyxia.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with the following injury that he sustained on being tackled by an opponent during the course of a hockey match. As the doctor, you would enter the wound description in the case sheet as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laceration

The given image shows a laceration. A laceration is a tear or a split in the skin, mucous membrane, muscle, or any internal organ, with a depth spanning more than the covering epithelium of the skin or an organ, and is produced by blunt force.

questions.text: You observe a forensic surgeon doing en masse removal of organs during an autopsy. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he performing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Letulle technique

The en masse removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique. It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. They are subsequently dissected into organ blocks.

questions.text: A 6 year old  Child was operated for Adeno-tonsillectomy under general anaesthesia. In the evening, patient develops neck spasm and is excessively crying. MRI Neck shows Atlantoaxial subluxation? What is the possible diagnosis in this case-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
Grisel Syndrome
Ref:Read the text below.
Sol:-
•	Grisel’s syndrome, subluxation of the atlanto-axial joint, not associated with trauma or bone disease, is found primarily in children. 
•	This syndrome has been observed after otolaryngologic procedures such as adenoidectomy. It presents with torticollis, neck stiffness.
•	X-rays and computed tomography scans of the cervical spine can confirm the diagnosis. Early management, consisting of cervical immobilization and medical treatment, is considered the key factor for a satisfactory outcome. 
•	Neurological complications have been reported in the literature, ranging from mild paresthesia, clonus, to quadriplegia or acute respiratory failure and death so neurosurgical consultation is required. 
•	This complication is more common in Down’s syndrome children.

250 mm

•	It has focal length of ~ 25 cm (= 10 inch) The examiner sees through the hole in the centre of the mirror
•	Diameter of central hole = 19 mm (3/4 inch)

questions.text:
A 75 yrs old patient of T4NoMo carcinoma larynx has undergone total laryngectomy. He has permanent tracheostomy following this surgery. He is using the device given in picture for vocal rehabilitation?

What is the name of this device?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Electrolarynx device. Ref: Read the text below. Sol:- Electrolarynx or artificial larynx is a hand held device.

• Blom singer prosthesis is a tracheoesophageal puncture device. • It is a one way valve surgically placed between trachea and esophagus. • It is used for vocal rehabilitation after laryngectomy. • It sends air from trachea to esophagus which is used to produce voice. • But it does not let the food particles to go from esophagus to trachea so aspiration is not significant.
