Modified young’s operation is the total closure of nostrils

questions.text: All of the following are features of atrophic rhinitis except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Modified young’s operation is the total closure of nostrils Ref: Read the text below Sol: The surgical management of atrophic rhinitis includes --- A.Young's operation:- - Complete Closure of one nostril B. Modified Young's operation:- - partial closure of both nostrils leaving behind a 3mm hole C. Lautenslager's operation:- Surgical procedures aimed at medializing the lateral nasal wall by injecting Substance like Paraffin , teflon, polythene , cartilage

questions.text:
A 2 year old child presents to emergency with high grade fever and respiratory distress. He has drooling of saliva and her mother told he has been refusing feeds since yesterday. On oral examination there was a bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of midline. Xray soft tissue neck lateral view is shown in picture.

What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute Retropharyngeal abscess. Ref:Read the text below. Sol:- Retropharyngeal Space - Between the buccopharyngeal fascia covering the pharyngeal constrictor & the prevertebral fascia. • Extends from base of skull to bifurcation of trachea. • Divided by a fibrous raphe into 2 (spaces of Gilette). • Abscess causes U/L bulge on post pharyngeal wall. Acute retropharyngeal abscess - Commonly seen in children < 3yrs. • Results of suppuration of retropharyngeal LN. • In adults - from penetrating injury of post. pharyngeal wall. • C/F : * Dysphagia & difficulty in breathing (prominent symp). • Stridor & croupy cough. • Torticollis. • Bulge in post. Pharyngeal wall (usually seen on one side of midline). • Xray Soft tissue neck lat. view - widening of prevertebral shadow. • T/t - I & D without GA, antibiotics.

choices.text: Cutting drill over the bleeding area
Diamond drill over the bleeding are
Bipolar cautery over the bleeding area

questions.text: All of the following techniques are used to control bleeding from bone during mastoid surgery except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 
Cutting drill over the bleeding area
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
•	Diamond drill over the bleeding area will produce heat and stop the bleeding.
•	Bipolar cautery can be used to control bleeding during mastoid surgery (Not monopolar cautery).
•	Bone wax is also commonly used to control bleeding during mastoid surgery (It seals the bleeding site).

choices.text: The patient should be placed head down supine with a pillow under the shoulders.
Trotter's method includes encouraging the patient to swallow the blood, to allay psychological stress and thereby reduce blood pressure.
A postnasal pack should be considered in severe epistaxis.
A central venous pressure line is mandatory

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate statement regarding Initial treatment of severe epistaxis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
A postnasal pack should be considered in severe epistaxis..
Ref:Read the text below.
Sol:-
•	The patient should be seated in a chair, leaning forward, breathing through the open mouth, and allowing blood to drip into a bowl. 
•	The anterior part of the nose is compressed between finger and thumb to put pressure on Little's area, which is the site of bleeding in 90% of cases. 
•	A postnasal pack should be considered in severe epistaxis.

questions.text: Intranasal examination shows bilaterally symmetrical, bluish, fluctuant swelling in the anterior part of the nasal septum; this is suggestive of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
Septal hematoma.
Ref:Read the text below.
Sol:-
•	A nasal septal hematoma occurs when blood collects in the space between the septal cartilage and the overlying mucoperichondrium.
•	It is classically bilateral and follows nasal trauma, although bleeding disorders, violent sneezing and anticoagulant drugs like aspirin and warfarin are also attributed to its development. 
•	The buckling force strips the perichondrium off the cartilage, tearing the submucosal blood vessels, resulting in a hematoma. 
•	If not drained immediately, the cartilage may undergo necrosis as it is deprived of its nutrition, leading to saddle nose deformity, supra tip collapse and columellar retraction. Undue delay in diagnosis and treatment can also lead to septal abscess, septal perforation and direct spread of infection to cavernous sinus via emissary veins. 
•	Hence, all patients with nasal trauma should be evaluated for septal hematoma, and immediate surgical drainage along with nasal packing for 2–3 d (to prevent recurrence) is warranted to avoid complications.

questions.text: All are the causes except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
This is the clinical picture of vortex keratopathy also called cornea verticillata where there is whorl-like deposition of drug on the cornea. Chlorpromazine is the deposition of the drug on the corneal endothelium.

choices.text: Soft exudate, central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. Fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


The given image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with crenated margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Among the above options, -1.00 DC x 180 degrees is the correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism (SMA). Simple myopic astigmatism (SMA): One principal meridian is on the retina, whereas the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.

questions.text: During a community outreach program in a rural area, you come across a girl with a conjunctival lesion as shown in the image. According to the WHO grading, which grade does this child falls under?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given image shows Bitot's spot, which is seen in the X1B stage of vitamin A deficiency. The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia. The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis. The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

questions.text: A patient sustained a severe blow to the right eye from the lateral side during a fistfight. The eyeball is soft to touch and a rupture of the sclera is suspected. What is the least likely site of rupture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The lateral limbus is the least likely site to be involved in a traumatic scleral rupture. It usually occurs at the insertion of rectus muscles, at the equator, or in an area parallel to the limbus opposite from the site of the impact.

questions.text: The innermost layer of the sclera is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lamina fusca Lamina fusca is the innermost layer of the sclera, facing the choroid (suprachoroidal space). Lamina fusca is the transition zone between the sclera and the choroid. It consists of a delicate meshwork of elastic fibers, fibrocytes, melanocytes, traversed by long posterior ciliary nerves and vessels.

questions.text: Among the following, the first muscle to be affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The first muscle to be affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis is the lateral rectus. Ophthalmoplegia in cavernous sinus thrombosis occurs in the following sequence: 6th nerve palsy (lateral rectus palsy) occurring first of all as it passes through the cavernous sinus. 3rd and 4th nerves are involved later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: All of the following are seen  following blunt trauma to the eye except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Soemmering’s ring Soemmering's ring is not seen after blunt trauma to the eye Soemmering's ring refers to a thick ring of after cataract, also known as "secondary cataract.’ It is the opacity which persists or develops after extracapsular lens extraction.

questions.text: Which drug should not be used in a uveitis with raised IOP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pilocarpine 
Pilocarpine should not be used in cases of uveitis with raised intraocular pressure since it causes miosis and ciliary spasm. It also increases intraocular inflammation. Hence, it is not preferred in inflammatory glaucoma.

questions.text: The muscles producing the intorsion of the eyeball are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Superior rectus and superior oblique
 The muscles producing intorsion of the eyeball are superior rectus and superior oblique.

questions.text: A 28 year old presents with yellowish discoloration of sclera with mild similar episodes in childhood. Lab investigations shows normal liver enzymes, raised urine bilirubin and normal urinary coproporphyrin levels (type 1 > type 3). Gall bladder on oral cholangiography was not visualised. Which of the following is the possible cause of jaundice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dubin Johnson syndrome

The presence of urinary bilirubin indicates along with urinary coproporphyrin 1 more than 3 is likely to be Dubin Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man complains of epigastric pain which increases by food intake and concomitant weight loss. Endoscopy shows gastric ulcers. Which of the following is true about gastric ulcers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Low basal acid production

Gastric ulcers are associated with low basal acid production and low stimulated acid production.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male comes to the OPD with intermittent jaundice for the past 2 months. You suspect acute viral hepatitis. Which of the following will you not evaluate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

IgM anti HBe

IgM anti-HBe is not one of the markers that are evaluated in a suspected case of acute viral hepatitis..

questions.text: Which of the following sites is most commonly involved in Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Terminal ileum

The most commonly affected site in Crohn’s disease is the terminal ileum.
Other commonly affected sites in Crohn’s disease include the small intestine and the colon. Although it can affect any part of the GI tract from mouth to anus, the rectum is usually spared.

questions.text: Non invasive test to detect hepatic fibrosis include:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

FibroTest

FibroTest is a sensitive test to detect hepatic fibrosis. It is a multiparameter blood test which incorporates haptoglobin, bilirubin, GGT, apolipoprotein A-I, and alpha-2 -macroglobulin.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of inflammatory bowel disease, which helps to rule out irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Faecal lactoferrin

Fecal lactoferrin is the marker of IBD that is used to rule out irritable bowel syndrome. Fecal lactoferrin is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation.

questions.text: In comparing the following neuroleptics, which is most likely associated with skeletal muscle rigidity, tremor at rest, flat facies, uncontrollable restlessness, and spastic torticollis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Haloperidol 

Haloperidol, a butyrophenone, is by far the most likely antipsychotic to produce extrapyramidal toxicities. Other agents, such as piperazine (an aromatic phenothiazine), thiothixene (a thioxanthene), and pimozide (a diphenylbutyropiperidine) are comparitively less likely to produce extrapyramidal toxicity than haloperidol.

questions.text: A pediatric patient treated for grand mal seizures develops abnormal values on liver function tests. Which of the following antiepileptic agents would cause this to occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Valproic acid 

Severe hepatotoxicity of an idiosyncratic nature is associated with valproic acid. The risk is very high in the pediatric population, particularly in patients below the age of two. Fatalities generally occur within four months of treatment. Hepatotoxicity may be reversed in some individuals.

choices.text: Increase in the frequency of the chloride channel opening

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with absence seizures is treated with ethosuximide. What is the principal mechanism of action of ethosuximide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Calcium channel blockade 

Ethosuximide is especially useful in the treatment of absence seizures. Although it may act at several sites, the principal mechanism of action is on T-type Ca currents in thalamic neurons at relevant concentrations. This action blocks the pacemaker current that effects the generation of rhythmic cortical discharge associated with an absence attack.

questions.text: A patient was referred to a neurologist with symptoms of Parkinsonism and was prescribed Levodopa. Which of the following problems do you think he would ensure the patient does not have before initiating the medicine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glaucoma 

Caution is advised in individuals with narrow-angle glaucoma, as Levodopa can elevate intraocular pressure. Extra care should be taken in patients with atrial nodal or ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: Which drug has a high affinity for 5-HT2 receptors in the brain and is reported to increase the risk of QT prolongation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ziprasidone

Ziprasidone can cause QT prolongation leading to torsades de pointes, especially in the presence of predisposing factors/drugs.

questions.text: The CT finding of a patient is shown below. What is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Injury to bridging dural veins

The given image is suggestive of a subdural hematoma and it most commonly results from injury to the bridging dural veins.

questions.text: A female presented with loss of pain and temperature, but her touch sensation was intact. Imaging showed cavitation around the central canal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Syringomyelia

The probable diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the image showing cavitation around the central canal is syringomyelia.

questions.text:
A patient comes to ED with fever and headache. On examination he has neck stiffness. CSF analysis was done and it shows the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Opening pressure – Increased
Proteins – Mildly increased
Glucose-Normal
Lymphocytes – Increased.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Viral meningitis

Meningitis with normal glucose is a tell-tale evidence of viral meningitis.

CSF findings in Viral meningitis:

- Mild increase in CSF protein/pressure

- Normal glucose

- Mild increase in lymphocytes in CSF

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic man presents with retrosternal chest pain and profuse sweating and lightheadedness. Based on the ECG findings, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anterior wall MI 

The ECG shows ST elevations in leads I, aVL, and V1- V6. This is suggestive of extensive anterior wall MI.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Diuretic

While a calcium channel blocker, beta blocker, or alpha- blocker can be part of the antihypertensive regimen, the Inclusion of a diuretic is necessary for the diagnosis of resistant hypertension. The diuretic helps in addressing fluid retention which is often a significant contributor to hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac biomarkers is the earliest to rise after acute myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Myoglobin

Myoglobin is the earliest to rise in acute MI followed by troponin, CK-MB and then LDH.

choices.text: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion
Positive echocardiogram not meeting major criteria

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the minor criteria of modified Duke criteria for clinical diagnosis of infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Positive echocardiogram not meeting major criteria

Positive echocardiogram not meeting major criteria was earlier a minor criterion but is now removed.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient was brought to the emergency due to complaints of palpitations and breathing difficulty. Comment on his ECG.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ventricular bigeminy

The above ECG shows a pattern of premature ventricular contractions, one premature beat after one normal beat. This is seen in ventricular bigeminy. Premature ventricular contractions/beats (PVC) are single ventricular beats that occur earlier than the next normal supraventricular beat.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female is admitted with palpitations. Her pulse is 220 beats/min, blood pressure 70/50 mmHg and she has a respiratory rate 32/min. She is awake, alert and oriented but dyspnoeic. Her electrocardiogram shows a regular rhythm with QRS complex width of 0.11 s. What is the most appropriate therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Direct current cardioversion 

This is highly likely to be a narrow complex tachycardia. Strictly speaking, as this patient is showing signs of haemodynamic compromise (that is, systolic blood pressure less than 90) she should be immediately DC cardioverted under sedation/anaesthesia. In practice, most people would try adenosine first whilst organising a cardioversion.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man with insulin-dependent diabetes given ibuprofen for a knee injury is admitted with palpitations. His ECG shows a rate of 105 beats per minute, with absent P waves and tall T waves. His urea and electrolytes show: Na:132 mmol/L, K+: 6.4 mmol/L, Urea 11 mmol/L, Creatinine 180 pmol/L. In this scenario, which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Calcium chloride 10 mmol IV
The ECG suggests cardiotoxicity related to hyperkalaemia and the history of palpitations is suggestive of arrhythmias. Therefore cardio protection with calcium chloride or gluconate should be first priority and lowering potassium levels immediately thereafter.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male is admitted with a 30 minute history of central chest pain associated with nausea and sweating. His ECG reveals ST elevation in leads Il, Ill, and aVF. Which of the following coronary arteries is most likely to be occluded?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Right coronary artery

The patient has had an inferior myocardial infarction (MI) and this is most likely due to occlusion of the right coronary artery.

questions.text: Deficiency of which one of the following trace elements is implicated as a cause of cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Selenium 

Selenium deficiency is one of the reversible causes of dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who has symptoms of frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis, along with a 24-hour urine volume of 7 liters, a urine osmolarity of 260 mOsm/L, an ADH assay result of 0.8 pg/ml, and a brain MRI showing no bright spot on T1 weighted images?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 

Pituitary DI 
Pituitary DI (diabetes insipidus) • The patient's presentation of frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis along with a 24-hour urine volume of 7 liters and low urine osmolarity indicates the inability to concentrate urine, which is a characteristic feature of diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A hepatitis B positive person came to your opd on routine urine, massive proteinuria (> 3.5 g/day), Further renal biopsy was performed. identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

Membranous glomerulonephritis 
 

Based on the presentation of a patient with Hepatitis B and heavy proteinuria the most likely finding on renal biopsy would be membranous glomerulonephritis. Membranous glomerulonephritis is a type of glomerular disease characterized by the thickening and immune complex deposition along the glomerular basement membrane. It can be associated with various underlying conditions, including solid tumors. The diffuse capillary and GBM thickening is characteristic finding

questions.text: A young man presents with the following painful, soft ulcer, 4 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. Which of the following will you choose as initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation: Azithromycin 1g oral stat (as a single dose) is a highly recommended first-line treatment for chancroid according to major health guidelines (e.g., CDC). It is effective, administered orally, and the single-dose regimen promotes patient compliance, which is crucial in treating sexually transmitted infections. The clinical presentation (painful, soft ulcer appearing 4 days after unprotected intercourse) is classic for chancroid.

Incorrect Options:

Option (A) Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM stat

Explanation: Ceftriaxone is an effective treatment for chancroid, and a single intramuscular (IM) dose is a recommended approach. However, the standard recommended dose is usually 250 mg IM. While a 500 mg dose would likely be effective, it is higher than the typically cited standard single dose, making Azithromycin 1g oral (which is a standard recommended dose) a more precise choice among the options.

Option (B) Ciprofloxacin 500 mg BD for 4 days

Explanation: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally twice daily (BD) is a recommended treatment for chancroid, but the standard duration is for 3 days. While a 4-day course would likely be effective, it deviates from the standard recommended multi-dose regimen and is less preferable than a single-dose regimen like Azithromycin for initial treatment when compliance is a consideration.

Option (C) Erythromycin 500 mg QID for 7 days

Explanation: Erythromycin base 500 mg orally is a recommended treatment for chancroid, but the standard dosing is typically three times a day (TID) for 7 days. QID (four times a day) is a higher frequency than standard and, being a multi-dose regimen over 7 days, it is generally less preferred than a single-dose therapy for initial treatment due to potential compliance issues.

questions.text: Pemphigus is an autoimmune disease caused by antibodies directed against proteins present in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Desmosomes Pemphigus is an autoimmune disease caused by antibodies directed against both desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3 present in desmosomes. Loss of desmosomes results in loss of cohesion between keratinocytes in the epidermis and a disruption of the barrier function served by intact skin.

questions.text: This section was taken from a patient diagnosed with Psoriasis. What is the arrow pointing to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Munro's microabscess In this given image, the arrow points to a small collection of neutrophils is seen within stratum corneum. This is a Munro's microabscess. Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis is also seen here.

choices.text: It mostly appears at birth or early childhood.
Iti s distributed along trigeminal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Seen more in males 

Naevus of Ota is more commonly seen in females. A naevus of Ota is an extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis. A large number of elongated dendritic melanocytes can be seen scattered among collagen bundles mainly of the superficial dermis. It affects the sclera and the skin adjacent to the eye. Distributed along the first and the second branches of the trigeminal nerve. Most lesions are present at birth or develop during the first year of life, increasing in size and number in subsequent years.  Lesions are more common in females and in Asians.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is dorsal pterygium as shown of nail observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lichen planus 

Nail Pterygium is a wing-shaped deformity of nail due to a central fibrotic band which divides the nail into two parts in the proximal area. Dorsal pterygium is seen in lichen planus.  Ventral pterygium is seen in trauma, systemic sclerosis, Raynaud phenomenon, lupus erythematosus, familial subungual pterygium, and infections

questions.text: A patient who was admitted after a road traffic accident is put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

The patients GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.

questions.text: A woman presented with a BIRADS-5 breast lesion. Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ER positive

ER positivity is a good prognostic factor in breast cancer.

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presented with pain abdomen. The resident examines the child and found that vitals were stable and tenderness was present in the left lumbar region. Which is the best investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Contrast enhanced CT scan 

The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a road traffic accident is suggestive of blunt renal trauma. The investigation of choice is CECT in a hemodynamically stable patient.

questions.text: What is the most common site of distant metastasis in patients with medullary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Liver

Liver metastasis is more common in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: Patient presents with peritonitis and during surgery, a diverticular perforation is seen with fecal peritonitis. What is the Hinchey's stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Stage 4

Fecal peritonitis belongs to grade 4 in the Hinchey classification.

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue. On imaging, she was found to have a scleroatrophic gall bladder with impacted stones in it. A large stone was also present in the common bile duct and the biliary tree is dilated. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

ERCP is the next line of management for this patient. The most common indication for therapeutic ERCP is the relief of biliary obstruction.

questions.text: A woman presented with a BIRADS-5 breast lesion. Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ER positive

ER positivity is a good prognostic factor in breast cancer. The ER and PR are two steroid hormone receptors present in breast cancer. The expression of these receptors indicates a favorable prognosis and response to hormonal therapy.

questions.text: Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS) includes which of the following components?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RTS + ISS + age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) includes:

Injury Severity Score (ISS)

Revised Trauma Score (RTS)

Age

Mechanism of injury (blunt/penetrating).

questions.text: A patient with a solitary, 2x3 cm, nodular thyroid swelling came to your clinic with a recent report that showed elevated T4 and normal TSH levels. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ultrasound

Ultrasonography is the next best step in the evaluation of a euthyroid (normal TSH) patient with a solitary thyroid nodule. USG is a non-invasive and inexpensive way to stratify the risk of the nodule into benign or malignant tissue. Benign nodules are easily compressible and can be seen to deform by applying pressure with the probe while performing USG. Malignant nodules tend to be hard and firm.

questions.text: A 77-year-old lady with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis presents with hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and elevated PTH. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Subtotal parathyroidectomy

The patient’s long-standing renal failure and elevated calcium, phosphate, and PTH are suggestive of tertiary hyperparathyroidism. This form of hyperparathyroidism can be life-threatening, and all patients with it should be referred for surgical intervention. The surgical procedure of choice for tertiary hyperparathyroidism is subtotal parathyroidectomy. In subtotal parathyroidectomy, the affected glands are completely removed and the least affected gland is partially resected.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain and swelling in the genital area. He has a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and is currently on insulin therapy. On examination, the patient appears toxic, with a temperature of 39.5°C (103.1°F), tachycardia, and hypotension. His genital region is edematous, erythematous, and extremely tender to touch. Finding is as shown in image. Which of the following features is NOT typically associated with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Testicles are involved 

Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive, life-threatening necrotizing fasciitis that primarily affects the genital and perineal regions. It is characterized by a polymicrobial infection involving aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. The infection spreads along the fascial planes, leading to tissue destruction and necrosis. Testicular involvement is rare in Fournier's gangrene because of the separate blood supply to the testes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a non-healing ulcer on his lower leg. He reports that the ulcer has been present for several months and has gradually increased in size. On examination, there is a large, irregularly shaped ulcer with raised, rolled edges. The base of the ulcer is necrotic, and there is foul-smelling discharge. The patient has a history of a burn injury in the same area several years ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Marjolin ulcer

Based on the clinical presentation, the most likely diagnosis is D) Marjolin ulcer. Marjolin ulcer is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that arises in chronic non-healing wounds or scars, such as burn injuries or chronic ulcers. It typically presents as an irregularly shaped ulcer with raised, rolled edges. The base of the ulcer may be necrotic, and there can be foul-smelling discharge. Marjolin ulcers often have a delayed onset, appearing months to years after the initial injury.

choices.text: Decreased platelet count and prolonged prothrombin time
Petechial rash and altered mental status

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is admitted to the hospital after a long bone fracture. Two days later, he develops acute respiratory distress, petechial rash, and neurological abnormalities. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Which of the following clinical findings is most consistent with fat embolism syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Petechial rash and altered mental status


Fat embolism syndrome (FES) is a condition characterized by the systemic release of fat globules into the bloodstream, typically following long bone fractures or major orthopedic surgeries. It can result in respiratory distress, neurologic abnormalities, and petechial rash. The classic triad of clinical manifestations seen in fat embolism syndrome includes respiratory distress, neurologic abnormalities, and petechial rash.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a routine screening colonoscopy, which reveals a 2 cm pedunculated polyp in the sigmoid colon. The histopathological examination of the polyp shows low-grade dysplasia. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Surgical resection

The presence of a 2 cm pedunculated polyp with low-grade dysplasia raises concern for the potential of adenomatous transformation and malignant progression. Surgical resection is the most appropriate management for this patient. Endoscopic mucosal resection  and cold snare polypectomy are suitable for smaller polyps without features concerning for malignancy.

choices.text: It is due to lack of inhibitory neurons in Auerbach plexus
Characterized by classical triad of dysphagia, regurgitation and weight loss
Barium swallow is gold standard investigation
Heller’s cardiomyotomy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A 40 years old female presented to OPD with complaints of retrosternal heartburn, dysphagia more for liquids and occasional aspiration. Barium swallow is given below. Which of the following statement is false about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Barium swallow is gold standard investigation

High-resolution manometry (HRM) is the gold standard test for the diagnosis of achalasia. Conventional manometry tracings in patients with achalasia show the absence of esophageal peristalsis and incomplete LES relaxation with residual pressures of over 10 mm Hg.

choices.text: Partial thickness tear involving mucosa & submucosa
Bleeding occurs mainly from gastroduodenal artery
Use of Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is contraindicated

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct about Mallory-Weiss syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bleeding occurs mainly from gastroduodenal artery

Mallory-Weiss syndrome is characterized by longitudinal mucosal lacerations (intramural dissection) in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach, which are usually associated with forceful or prolonged vomiting or retching. The lacerations often lead to bleeding from submucosal arterial plexus.

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of greater curvature of stomach

questions.text: Most common complication of splenectomy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Atelectasis

Atelectasis is a common postoperative complication and should be suspected whenever elevations of temperature, pulse rate and respiratory rate develop in a patient shortly after operation. Generally it is due to either bronchial obstruction with distal gas absorption or Due to hypoventilation.

choices.text: Duodenoduodenostomy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct about annular pancreas except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Associated with bilious vomiting

Annular pancreas, which may be seen at any age, should be considered in the differential diagnosis of patients with non-bilious vomiting, particularly after meals, over a long period.

choices.text: Most common clinical presentation is pain and tenderness in calf
Some cases may directly present as pulmonary thromboembolism

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mostly bilateral

Most cases of DVT are unilateral. Bilateral cases are seen in 30% of individuals. Common sites include pelvic veins and femoral and popliteal veins (left side more common)

questions.text: Which of the following method is shown in the surgical procedure to close the abdominal wound with the help of a mesh?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Intraperitoneal (Underlay) 

Underlay repair is when the mesh is placed in the intraperitoneal position and secured to the anterior abdominal wall. In sublay, the mesh is placed behind the rectus muscle and in front of the posterior rectus sheath, whereas in the inlay technique, the mesh is anchored in line with the fascial defect. Onlay mesh is placed directly on top of the anterior fascia.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with flame burns. On clinical evaluation there were deep burns involving the left upper limb, the right upper limb and the anterior aspect of chest and abdomen. How much percentage of burns would it be classified as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

36% 

The front and back of the head and neck equal 9% of the body's surface area. The front and back of each arm and hand equal 9% of the body's surface area. The chest equals 9% and the stomach equals 9% of the body's surface area. The upper back equals 9% and the lower back equals 9% of the body's surface area.
In this case:
Left upper limb (9%)
Right upper limb (9%)
Anterior aspect of chest (9%)
Anterior aspect of abdomen (9%)
Total percentage of burn: 36%

questions.text: Small punched out lesions on endoscopy in lower esophagus in the immunocompromised patients is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Herpes simplex esophagitis 

Herpes simplex virus type 1 or 2 may cause esophagitis. Vesicles on the nose and lips may coexist and are suggestive of a herpetic etiology. Varicella-zoster virus can also cause esophagitis in children with chickenpox or adults with zoster. The characteristic endoscopic findings are vesicles and small, punched-out ulcerations.

choices.text: The second-born male is commonly affected

questions.text: A 4-week-old male baby is brought to the casualty by his parents with complaints of recurrent episodes of non-bilious vomiting. The child also refuses to take adequate feeds. The child is hypotensive and tachypneic. Ultrasound abdomen reveals features consistent with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which of the following is most likely associated with this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ramstedt operation is done

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a history of colicky pain, multiple episodes of bilious vomiting, no passage of flatus, and constipation shows a distended abdomen with a tympanic note. The X-ray of the abdomen is done as shown in the image: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Jejunal obstruction 

No passage of flatus suggests small bowel obstruction. X-ray of the abdomen shows  1. Multiple dilated bowel loops 2. Circumferential ring-like pattern indicating → JEJUNAL OBSTRUCTION. VALVULAE CONNIVENTES Small Bowel Obstruction: Valvulae conniventes are straight segments that cross the bowel width and appear like a ladder. They are mostly visible in the jejunum. In SBO, colon gas may be minimal or absent due to the obstruction. Large bowel Obstruction:  Haustral folds are irregular folds in the colon that lack opposite indentations and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. They are commonly seen in the colon and cecum. In LBO, a distended cecum may appear as a round gas shadow in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented to the clinic with the complaint of painless fresh rectal bleeding for 2 weeks. He denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, tenderness, etc. The doctor suspects the bleeding is coming from Meckel's diverticulum. What would be the best diagnostic modality for this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Radioisotope scanning with technetium-99m 

Complaint of fresh rectal bleeding that is painless without any other symptoms is usually suggestive of Meckel’s diverticulum, and the best diagnostic modality is radioisotope scanning with technetium-99m. It is a persistent remnant of the vitellointestinal duct and is present in about 2% of the population; it is found on the antimesenteric side of the ileum, usually approximately 60cm from the ileocaecal valve, and is classically 5cm long.  It contains all three coats of the bowel wall with its blood supply and is congenital. It usually presents with hemorrhage when gastric mucosa is inside and presents as painless fresh or dark rectal bleeding. If not removed, it can lead to diverticulitis, chronic ulceration, intussusception, intestinal obstruction, and perforation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper arm and a history of a trivial fall a few days ago. His X-ray is given below. Which of the following is not a treatment modality for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Radiotherapy

Radiotherapy is not a treatment modality used in the treatment of the above condition. The given X-ray reveals a fracture running through a central cystic lesion situated on the proximal humeral metaphysis, and also shows a fallen fragment sign. This along with the clinical scenario (male within 2nd decade of life) is strongly suggestive of a unicameral bone cyst (simple bone cyst).

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the final stage of Pott’s paraplegia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Flaccid paralysis

Flaccid paralysis is seen in the final stage of Pott’s paraplegia. Pott’s paraplegia begins as a UMN lesion. So initially, the patient is asymptomatic but ankle clonus, increased deep tendon reflexes, and extensor plantar can be detected on clinical examination.

choices.text: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.text: A 23-year-old man who had a road traffic accident is brought to the casualty. His right leg is shortened, internally rotated and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Posterior dislocation of hip 
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of posterior hip dislocation. In this condition, the leg will be in flexion, adduction and internal rotation.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of fall few months back presents with the deformity shown in the image. Probing into history reveals it was managed with traditional treatment. This deformity is likely to be due to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Extra-articular fracture of wrist

The given image shows the dinner-fork deformity seen in Colle’s fracture which is an extra-articular fracture of the wrist.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used for diagnosis of osteoporosis ? 

A. DEXA 

B. Bone scan 

C. Quantitative CT 

D. Chemical analysis

E. X-ray
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bone scan is not used in the diagnosis of osteoporosis.

Osteoporosis is a reduction in bone mass (density) i.e. there is a quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has a qualitatively normal configuration. 

Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA Scan and it is matched to DEXA Scan of a 30-year-old individual and T score is calculated.

questions.text: An unresponsive child is brought to the ER. His BP is not recordable, pulse rate is 40 per minute. CPR is initiated but his SpO2 is 70% despite proper oxygenation and ventilation, and pulse rate is not improving. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

IV epinephrine

Epinephrine is the drug of choice for treating bradycardia in infants and children. The recommended dose is 0.01 mg/kg of a 1:10,000 solution. It can be given intravenously or via the intraosseous route. It can be repeated every 3-5 minutes.

questions.text: A patient who is under general anaesthesia shows the following finding on the ET CO2 monitor. Which condition can lead to this characteristic waveform on capnography?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bronchospasm

The above capnographic waveform depicts bronchospasm.
Shark fin appearance Prolonged phase II, increased alpha angle, and steeper phase III suggest bronchospasm or airway obstruction.

questions.text: Identify the Mallampatti class of this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


The image shows Mallampatti class Il airway. The modified Mallampatti classification is used in the assessment of airway. It is a predictor of the difficulty of intubation or difficult airway.

questions.text: Epidural anesthesia involves local anesthetic administration between:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dura and ligamentum flavum

Epidural anesthesia involves local anesthetic administration between the dura and ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: Which of the following inhalational agents has the least blood-gas partition coefficient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Desflurane 

Desflurane is the inhalational anesthetic agent with the least blood-gas partition coefficient. Among the commonly used inhalational anesthetics, desflurane is the least fat-soluble which leads to a faster recovery. Desflurane is also minimally metabolized by the liver, thereby reducing hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: A 17-year-old adolescent suffers from bulimia nervosa and is very depressed. She is also suffering from insomnia and apathy. Which of the following medications should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bupropion

Seizure disorders and eating disorders are contraindications for bupropion because of its possible lowering of the seizure threshold and its anorectic effects.

questions.text: Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hoarding behavior shows poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention.Challenges posed by hoarding patients to typical cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) include poor insight into the behavior, low motivation, and resistance to treatment.

questions.text: Which symptom is more likely to be found in a patient with social phobia-related panic attacks than in a patient with a primary panic disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Expected occurrence 
Panic attacks can occur in both social phobia as well as in patients with panic disorder. In patients with social phobia however these panic attacks occur with specific social situations and can be expected to occur there. In panic disorder however, the attacks may occur at any time.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

questions.text: A young child wakes up in the middle of the night screaming, frightened, and running to his parents room in this state. He is consolable and recalls a frightening dream in the morning at breakfast. In which stage of sleep did this nightmare likely occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Rapid eye movement sleep

Nightmare disorder is a parasomnia usually associated with the REM stage of sleep. Night terrors usually occur during non-REM sleep.

questions.text: A nulliparous woman has been using Today sponge as a contraceptive. What does this contain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nonoxynol 9 
Today sponge contains 1 g of nonoxynol 9. It is a mushroom- shaped polyurethane disposable sponge that is 2 inches wide and 1.25 inches thick.
It is provided with a loop for easy removal. It should be placed high up in the vagina with the concave side covering the cervix. It can remain effective for 24 h. It can be used only once.

choices.text: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

Minipills or progesterone-only pills (POP) do not kill sperm in the cervical canal. Progesterone-only pills act by thickening the cervical mucus (the main mechanism of all POPs except cerazette) that inhibits penetration of sperms, inhibiting tubal motility, and suppressing ovulation.
Other advantages of POPs include a reduction in the Incidence of pelvic inflammatory diseases and sexually transmitted diseases (due to thickened cervical mucus).

choices.text: 21 days on the pill, 7 days off
14 days on the pill, 14 days off
28 days on the pill, no break
7 days on the pill, 21 days off

questions.text: What is the typical regimen for taking combined oral contraceptive pills?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 21 days on the pill, 7 days off
The typical regimen for combined oral contraceptive pills is 21 days of active pills followed by a 7-day break (or 7 days of placebo pills) during which withdrawal bleeding occurs.

choices.text: Skip the missed pill and take the next pill as scheduled
Take the missed pill as soon as remembered and continue the rest as scheduled
Stop the pills and wait for the next cycle
Take two pills immediately and continue as normal

questions.text: What should be done if a woman misses one combined oral contraceptive pill?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Take the missed pill as soon as remembered and continue the rest as scheduled
 If a woman misses one combined oral contraceptive pill, she should take the missed pill as soon as she remembers and then continue taking the rest of the pills as scheduled. This helps maintain hormone levels and contraceptive efficacy.

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and asprin

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The next appropriate step in the management of a pregnant woman with a prosthetic valve on warfarin therapy at 36 weeks of gestation is to stop warfarin and start low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient was found to have uterus didelphys. Which of the following is not likely to be a complication of this uterine anomaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Among the given options, transverse lie is not a likely complication of uterus didelphys. A transverse lie is more likely to be seen with an arcuate or sub-septate uterus.

questions.text: The ultrasound of a young woman with infertility is suggestive of a uterine anomaly. Which of the following is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy

Hysteroscopy with laparoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis. For infertility evaluation, hysteroscopy and laparoscopy can detect müllerian anomalies, screen for co-existent endometriosis, and exclude other tubal or uterine cavity pathology. Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy can confirm both the internal and the external contour of the uterus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman, on examination was found to have infra-umbilical flattening. The fetal heart sounds were heard over the lateral side. What could be the fetal presentation/position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Occipitoposterior

The presence of infra-umbilical flattening and fetal heart sounds on the lateral side indicates that the fetus is in the occipito-posterior position.

questions.text: A 28-year old pregnant woman came for a routine antenatal check-up in her second trimester. Four years back, she delivered 2 healthy full-term twins. What would her obstetric score be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 

G2P1
 

The obstetric score of a pregnant woman who previously delivered twins would be G2P1 (gravida 2 para 1).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Crown rump length by USG

The best method of assessing the gestational age of a patient on oral contraceptives Six weeks of amenorrhea is by measuring the crown-rump length (CRL) using ultrasonography.

choices.text: She is at significant risk for endometrial cancer
She is at increased risk for ovarian cancer
She is at increased risk for osteoporosis
She is at increased risk for multiple gestations

questions.text: A 32-year-old G1P1 woman presents with an 8-month history of amenorrhea. A pregnancy test is negative. TSH and prolactin levels are normal. The FSH level is elevated at 40 IU/L. Which of the following is the most likely complication for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 

She is at increased risk for osteoporosis
 

This patient has secondary amenorrhea. Her pregnancy test is negative. The TSH and prolactin levels are normal. Her serum FSH level is elevated, indicating that she has premature ovarian failure. Due to the low estrogen levels, she is at risk for osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old G0P0 woman is told by her doctor that there is a strong probability that her gonads will turn malignant. She has not had her menses yet. She has Tanner stage I breast development. Which of the following describes the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


 The Y-chromosome gonad may become malignant. This patient likely has gonadal dysgenesis since she has Tanner stage I breast development. Although usually 45,X is associated with gonadal dysgenesis, the karyotype can also be 46,XX or 46,XY. In other words, this patient has delayed puberty. This is XY gonadal dysgenesis.

questions.text: A patient with suspected tubal pregnancy underwent transvaginal ultrasound which was inconclusive. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Serum Beta HCG levels

In the given scenario, the next step would be to confirm the tubal ectopic by measuring serum Beta hCG. This can be used to differentiate tubal ectopic pregnancy from missed abortion and early intrauterine pregnancy.
If the level is 2000 IU/L, ectopic pregnancy is suspected. If the level is <2000 IU/L, a repeat serum Beta hCG is taken after 48 hours. If the levels are:
- Doubled early intrauterine pregnancy
- Decreased abortion
- Increased but less than doubled value=ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post- menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

Ovarian Follicular cyst
 

Among the given options, Ovarian Follicular cysts are least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding. They are usually asymptomatic unless they rupture, hemorrhage or the ovary undergoes torsion which would manifest as an acute abdomen. They occur when there is the failure of absorption of fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with a history of unprotected sex 96 hours ago. Which of the following emergency contraceptives can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

Intra uterine contraceptive device (IUCD) 
 

Since the patient had unprotected sex 96 hours ago, an intrauterine contraceptive device(IUCD) can be used for emergency contraception in this case. It can be inserted within 5 days of coitus as a method of emergency contraception. All other methods of emergency contraception mentioned above need to be administered within 72 hours.

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of lactation in the right order
1. Mammogenesis
2. Lactogenesis
3. Galactokinesis
4. Galactopoiesis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1-2-3-4

The correct order of lactation is: Mammogenesis – lactogenesis – galactokinesis – galactopoiesis

questions.text: A patient presents with constant leakage of urine and is diagnosed to have a genital fistula. Methylene blue swab test is done and the upper swab gets stained. Which of the following is the most likely type of fistula in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ureterovaginal fistula

The patient is most likely to have a vesicovaginal fistula.

choices.text: Large loop excision of transformation zone (LLETZ)

questions.text: Which of the following methods is most commonly used for the treatment of CIN?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Large loop excision of transformation zone (LLETZ)
 Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ) is the most commonly used treatment option for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). This procedure is also known as loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP).

questions.text: Which among the following HPV serotypes is most commonly associated with Ca cervix?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

16
 

HPV 16 is the most common type associated with Ca cervix. HPV 18 is the most malignant serotype of HPV.

questions.text: A 28-year-old infertile male underwent semen analysis. Results show: sperm concentration - 16 million/ml: pH7.5: volume - 2 mL: no agglutination is seen. Morphology shows 60% normal and 60% motile sperms. The most likely diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


 This male with sperm concentration 16 million/mL is considered to be normospermia. According to the WHO 2010 criteria for semen analysis, the lower reference limit for normal sperm concentration is 15 million/mL.

questions.text: The day on which FSH levels are studied to detect the premenopausal stage is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

Day 2-5 after last menstrual period 
 Study of FSH level on day 2-5 after the last menstrual period detects premenopausal stage.

choices.text: Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L

questions.text: Which of the following is the endocrinological change of PCOD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


All of the above statements are true regarding the endocrinological feature of PCOD.

questions.text: Fibroid uterus may present with all of the following features except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

Amenorrhea 

Menstrual abnormalities in fibroid include menorrhagia and metrorrhagia and not amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

Septate uterus
 

The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the outpatient department with primary amenorrhea. She had normal breast development and pubic hair. On examination, the vagina was blind-ending and the uterus was not palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breasts, and pubic hair, with a blind-ending vagina and uterus not palpable, is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis. Absent uterus and vagina in a person with female genotype and phenotype are features of Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the postnatal ward of a hospital. You receive an HIV-positive patient on PND-1. Which of the following tests would you use to detect HIV in the baby?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HIV DNA PCR HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother is diagnosed using HIV DNA PCR. NACO recommends the use of a qualitative HIV-1 DNA PCR (NAT) in children aged <18months.

questions.text: A 9-month-old child was brought with frontal bossing and craniotabes. X-ray of the child showed widening of the wrist joint. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bowing of legs The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rickets. Lower limb deformities appear when the child starts to walk. Hence, bowing of legs will be less commonly seen in infants.

choices.text: Proximal part of the ileum is involved most frequently
It is associated with intestinal ischemia
It is more common in preterm infants

questions.text: A 2-week old infant with a birth weight of 1.8 Kg is being treated in the NICU for necrotizing enterocolitis. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Proximal part of the ileum is involved most frequently The distal ileum and the proximal colon are involved most frequently in necrotizing enterocolitis.

questions.text: A young infant is brought to you with a suspected developmental delay. The child is intently looking at his own hands. You would consider referring this child to a specialist if this milestone persists after.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 20 weeks Between 12 and 20 weeks, the child observes his own hands very intently. This milestone is called hand regard and it should disappear by 20 weeks. Its persistence after 20 weeks is considered abnormal. In a blind child, however, it may persist beyond 20 weeks normally and is called apparent hand regard.

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2SD. This is most likely due to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Low height for the age (height for age < -2SD) in children indicates chronic malnutrition and stunting.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus -3SD
Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following:
1. Weight-for-length (or height) below -3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
2. Presence of bipedal oedema
3. Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

questions.text: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear, that he reaches out to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth, is found to be cyanosed with irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate is 60 beats/min, and a grimace is seen with some flexion of extremities. The Apgar score for this newborn is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


In this baby
• Color, blue - score 0
• Heart rate, <100 beats/min - Score 1
• Grimace-score 1
• Some flexion of the extremities - Score 1
• Irregular respiration - Score 1
Thus total score is 4.

questions.text: A 10-day old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is hyper-alert with mydriasis. Examination shows hyperactive tendon reflexes and clonus. On investigations, a normal EEG is obtained. What stage of HIE is she in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Stage 1

Hyperactive tendon reflexes may be seen in stages 1 and 2; however, the infant is hyperalert with mydriasis and normal EEG findings in stage 1.

questions.text: Which numbered arrow indicates the lentiform nucleus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 51 The lentiform nucleus is comprised of the putamen and globus pallidus.

questions.text: A 9-year-old female child with history of head ache and visual disturbance. A CT image revealed a calcified solidcystic suprasellar lesion as show here. What could be your possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Craniopharyngioma Craniopharyngioma is heterogeneous in texture; the combination of solid, cystic, and calcification components is a clue to its diagnosis on imaging modalities. Adult Craniopharyngioma is primarily large irregular with 90% calcification and a cystic area, while Pediatric Craniopharyngioma is mostly solid and rarely with cysts and calcifications.

questions.text: A 20 year old male with h/o RTA presents with chest pain and dyspnea. eFAST was done and is sign of:.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pneumothorax Given Barcode sign signifies lung that is not Sliding associated with pneumothorax. This could represent various pathologies like pneumothorax, right mainstem intubation, etc.

questions.text: A 12 week old child presented with fever, cyanosis and fatigue. His chest X ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

The given X-ray shows figure of 8 or snowman appearance characteristic of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC). TAPVC refers to a condition in which pulmonary veins instead of draining into the left atrium drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly. This results in anomalous drainage Of pulmonary venous blood flow into the systemic venous circulation. It is a cyanotic heart disease With features Of congestive heart failure. The patients are irritable and have failure to thrive.

questions.text: A gallium-67 scan was performed on a patient and showed the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sarcoidosis This is due to symmetrical uptake Of gallium-67 into the nasopharynx, lacrimal glands, parotid glands due to bilateral involvement Of the glands in sarcoidosis. Given image shows Panda sign.
